course.subject: ECON
course.name: Economics of Uncertainty and Information
course.description: All human endeavors are constrained by limited knowledge about the laws of nature, external events in the past, present and future, how other people (including ourselves) are going to behave, etc. Life is filled with decision problems without perfect information of their consequences. In view of these, research on the decision making and strategic interaction under risk and uncertainty have been extremely active for the past few decades. This course aims to provide an introduction to this exciting field of research and suggestions for further exploration. The first part of the course is devoted to the economics of uncertainty and covers topics including the expected-utility model, market allocation of risks and asset pricing. The second part of the course is devoted to the economics of information and covers topics including moral hazard, bargaining, auction theory, mechanism design, and information aggregation in the market.
course.prerequisites: ECON 3014 OR (ECON 3113 AND ECON 3133)

reviews.author: tchuuuuuu
reviews.comment_content:
Course outline and topics:
1.Review of decision-making under uncertainty
 (Expected utility/ Risk preference/ Optimal risk bearing)
2. Market allocation of risk
 (General equilibrium of pure exchange economy/ The market of contingent claims/ Asset market/ CAPM)
3. Static games of incomplete information
 (Bayesian Nash equilibrium/ Auction/ Bargaining)
4. Information processing
 (Belief updating/ Common-value auction/ Voting)
5. Dynamic games of incomplete information 
  (Perfect Bayesian Nash equilibrium/ Information cascade/  Signalling and Reputation)
6. Mechanism design
 (Revelation principle/ Designing effcient mechanisms/ Designing second-best mechanisms)
----------------------------------------------------
7. Moral hazard (not covered)
 (Risk-incentive tradeoff/ Multitasking, dynamic incentives and career concern)


The content is based on examples and does not require much for the proof part (but definitely still requires lots of math). It is quite interesting and fruitful for students to study in this field as the course clearly established a picture to go depth in microeconomics. Instead of solely theories, you are able to apply those concepts in real-life applications after learning. I believe it is a good course in terms of fundamental knowledge in analytical research in economics. Well-designed lecture overall.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Pak Hung again is one of the best professors in ECON courses for explaining theories and math. Though the concepts are pretty abstract and hard to understand, he always provides a detailed explanation and examples to back up and is also willing to solve students' problems.
So I will say it is worth taking this course under his teaching if you are interested in ECON theories and would like to challenge yourself with some math skills. Overall I did not get good grades (for sure lol), but I would say the learning and the knowledge I experienced were wonderful hahaha.
Besides, the teaching assistant is passionate about solving your problem, he is skilled enough to give you advice and suggestions. Overall, this course on teaching is for sure excellent!!!

reviews.comment_workload:
Required solid knowledge in calculus, probabilities, expectations and algebra.
Six problem sets with one midterm exam and a cumulative final exam. Need time to be familiar with new theories and comprehend the concepts and math.
Midterms and finals are similar to problem sets, but slightly more difficult, be sure to get used to all problem sets.

reviews.author: rind
reviews.title: The third course in Microeconomics
reviews.comment_content:
The content is similar to previous offerings except the notion of General Equilibrium is introduced before Arrow-Debreu Equilibrium.

The first part of this course is about uncertainty. Studying how to make investment decision under uncertainty. Will dive deeper compared to Econ 3113 and Econ 3143 (Intertemporal Consumption).

The second part is about information. How private information in a game affect the equilibrium result and how to mitigate that. You will study something interesting like: Can we trust collective wisdom? The Herding Effect; Auction; Mechanism design...

I think the mechanism design part is the most inspiring part. If you study Economics to make the world a better place, you will be interested in this topic.

Quite mathematical demanding but very interesting. Just like the previous reviews, this course is example based so some example may require specific mathematical knowledge to understand. In general, you have to be comfortable with probabilities. But I think Pak Hung teach quite well in explaining the math part so I still recommend taking this course.

You can also fulfill Econ4670 by this course. However, since there is no paper requirement in this course, you have to do extra work. Considering the complexity of this course, I suggest using other course for Econ4670 if possible. But Pak Hung also gives very good instruction and timely response in writing the paper.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Again, Pak Hung is very good at explaining theory and math. The content of this course is quite difficult so quite a number of students asking questions after the class. But he will answer the questions patiently even after teaching 3 hours.

Tutorial sections will focus on solution of problem sets. One tutorial is used to teach lecture material because the progress laid back.

Problem set 15% (best n-1, graded by effort)
Midterm 26%
Final 56%

Participation + Problem set: everyone should get full marks.

Midterm:

Median: 65 High: 80
Upper Quartile: 73.75 Low: 31
Lower Quartile: 53.25
Me: 80/80

Final: Not released
My Grade: A+

Cannot determine the grade distribution in my case.
reviews.comment_workload:
No compulsory attendance but professor will only release lecture recording by demand (e.g. you're sick). I think attending lecture is a most because it is very difficult to study the slides alone. Videos during add-drop period/some challenging topics will be provided as well.

The main workload in on the exams. Personally I think Pak Hung has lowered the difficulty of the exams because too many students find this course too difficult. You are allowed to open everything except internet during the exams, and questions are quite similar to the problem sets (or even more easy in my point of view). You can see the median of midterm exam is quite high.

Also, the numerical answers are usually in simple form (usually no decimal points), so it is easier to do checking unlike Industrial Organization.

reviews.author: HarryY
reviews.title: Very good grade, nice Prof but hard course
reviews.comment_content:
Very hard contents. Honestly even after completing the course and obtained B+, I still dont really understand most of the content.

Note that this course requires a lot of calculus (mostly first order condition), however, even F.O.C can become complicated in some of the topics. Probability and Expected Value concepts will also appear in some of the chapters, which could be very difficult (for me)
reviews.comment_teaching: Very nice professor, he is willing to answer your questions and explains the concepts until you fully understand individually.
reviews.comment_grading:
Very good grade.

PS all full marks (Graded on efforts)
MidTerm = 65/80 (Max:80 ; Mean 62)
Final score is not announced

BTW, midterm and final are graded quite heavily on effort also. Even if u got the wrong final answer, as long as ur steps are right, u might get full mark in that question. (My friend and I checked the midterm paper)
reviews.comment_workload:
I think it really depends on your own since most grading aspects are graded based on efforts.

I personally spent hours or even days to try to solve the problem sets. However, even if u got all wrong and put random steps and answers in your PS, u could still get full marks if he or TA think u are putting efforts.
